field_reports.description:
• Location: Yazgand Village, Sangvor District, Tajikistan

    Incident: Severe flooding caused by heavy rainfall

    Summary:

    On February 1, 2024, at 4:30 PM, Sangvor District experienced severe flooding in Yazgand Village, caused by heavy rainfall. This incident resulted in significant damage to infrastructure and displacement of residents.

    Damage Assessment:

    Initial Assessment (February 1, 2024):
    53 houses were damaged:
    7 houses were completely destroyed.
    46 houses were flooded

    Updated Assessment (July 2, 2024):
    Displaced Families: 67 families.

    Response:

    Immediate Response:
    Local authorities are providing immediate assistance to affected families, including food, water, and temporary shelter.
    Long-Term Response:
    Resettlement plans are being developed for the affected families.
    Local authorities are working in the affected areas to assess the full extent of the damage and develop comprehensive recovery plans.

    Key Concerns:

    The full impact of the flooding is still being assessed.
    The long-term needs of the displaced families, including housing, livelihoods, and access to essential services, must be addressed.
    The potential for further flooding remains a concern, especially during the upcoming rainy season.

  • Source:
    Executive Secretary of Sangvor District
    Local authorities in the affected area

field_reports.description: The Torrential rains between 27–28 August 2023 triggered floods, landslides, and mudflows in many districts of Tajikistan.As a result of the natural disaster, 21 people died, including 17 people in Vahdat city, 2  people in Rudaki district and 2 people in Varzob district, among them 9 women, 8 men and 4 minors.Also, affected around 5 045 people (over 1,009 households). Mudflows caused significant damage to the 1009 houses.The largest numbers of destruction and losses were suffered by the districts of Vahdat, Rudaki, Varzob and I.Somoni, Dushanbe. Ranking based on the total economic loss, the number of affected population and damage caused to the residential infrastructure indicates that Vahdat town,Varzob, and Hissor districts were the most severely affected areas. The Government responded rapidly to the emergency with the evacuation of the affected population and salvage of assets and belongings. Necessary machinery and workforce had been made available for debris removal, restoration of road communications and other essential services, including electricity and water supplies. Essential healthcare was ensured through local healthcare facilities and mobile teams of medical staff were deployed to the affected areas.On the basis of the order of the President of the Republic of Tajikistan, a working group led by the Deputy Prime Minister of the country, the Chairman of the Committee for Emergency Situations and Civil Defense, the Director of the Land Sanitation and Irrigation Agency under the Government of the Republic of  Tajikistan  and representatives of other relevant structures and offices of the Republic visited the cities and districts of Vahdat, Hisor, Rudaki, Varzob. and took immediate measures to eliminate natural disasters.At the same time, the commissions of the executive bodies of the state authorities of cities and districts on emergency situations together with specialists of the Committee of Architecture and Construction of the Republic of Tajikistan and the Committee of Emergency Situations under the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan are working to determine the damage and the list of affected families, and measures are being taken to provide assistance.

results.name: TJK: Flood - 2023-08 - Floods/Mudflows/Landslides/Rockfalls, Tajikistan:
results.summary:
Heavy rainfall that occurred in Tajikistan on August 27-28, 2023, caused widespread flooding, mudflows, landslides, and rockfalls.

The affected areas include Dushanbe, Vahdat, and Hisor cities, and Rudaki, Varzob, Devashtich, Rasht, Sangvor, and Tojikobod districts.

As of August 30, 20 casualties have been reported, and the death toll is expected to rise as mud cleaning and debris removal operations continue.

The disaster has also damaged or destroyed homes, roads, bridges, schools, agricultural land, livestock, and other infrastructure.

The State Emergency Situations Commission (ESC) has been set up and is working to assess the full extent of the damage.

According to the preliminary assessment of the ESC as of 30 August, the disaster caused damage to 1,021 residential and auxiliary buildings and household/kitchen plots.

Local emergency services, supported by the local population, are engaged in response operations, including mud cleaning and debris removal.

field_reports.description:
The torrential rains of May 04-06, 2022 triggered floods, landslides and mudflows in many of the country’s districts. The largest number of losses and destructions are faced by districts and cities of Districts of Republican Subordination (DRS), Sughd and Khatlon provinces and Dushanbe city. CoES reports that disasters preliminary caused the different types of damages to 694 households. Out of 694 households 507 households are under the risk threat.  
 Dushanbe city and including districts Sino,I.Somoni,Shohmansur and Firdavsi 15 households were mudded.
DRS, In addition, on 6 May 2022 at about 01:45 local time heavy rainfall caused mudflow, as a result of which the mudflow filled 25 lands plots of Obsharon village of Choryakkoron Jamoat, 4 land plots of Esanboy jamoat, Khojabulbulon village 1 land plot and Magmurud village 12 land plot  of Rudaki district and 450 meters road were  filled with water. Also in 5th of May 600 meter of transport road were destroyed/ 
DRS, during the night of 5-6 May 2022. As a result of heavy rainfall in Zartepa village Durbog jamoat,Shurob village,Somon jamoat,Hisor and Sayod villages,Hisor jamoat 5 households were fully destroyed and 8 household were partially damaged . Also 400 meter road Dushanbe – Hisor destroyed.   
DRS, During the night of May 5-6, 2022 as a result of heavy rainfall the water level in Karatag, Shirkent, Khojanakshiron, Zarkamar and Mulloshodi rivers increased, leading to mudflows and flooding of 75 household plots in Hamadoni village of T.Tuychiev village Jamoat of Tursunzadev district.Also, heavy rains caused mudflows from the hills surrounding the village of Faizbakhsh rural Jamoat 10 - anniversary of Independence and there was 42 house hold partially damaged and  195 households under the threat.  M.Tursunzoda 312 households were evacuated via threat.1800 people were evacuated to safer place (schools and mosque).  
DRS, Vahdat town - at 00:00 in Simiganj, Chuyangaron and Romit Jamoats of Vahdat District on 6 May 2022, the water level in rivers exceeded the norm and created a threat of flooding on the Vahdat-Chuyangaron-Romit road. As a result of precipitation, the water level in the Kafernigan River increased and 1 km of the road was blocked by a muddy mass.  
Sugd region- In Devashtichi District, heavy rainfall and mudflows damaged the bridge running through Gazantarak Jamoat, as well as 9.7 km of the Dahanasoy water pipeline.   To eliminate the consequences of the disaster, the forces and means of the Unified State System for Prevention and Response to Emergency Situations of Devastich district were involved.
Sugd region - According to preliminary data, at 16:30 on May 5, 2022 in Penjikent city of Sughd region as a result of heavy rains 15 cattle of the local population were killed in the village of Nuriston of rural Jamoat Chinor because of the mudflow.  
Sugd region - Mudflows caused partial damage to household plots of local residents in Temurmalik and Navbunyod rural Jamoat of B.Gafurov District, Sughd Region, at around 17:10 pm on May 5, 2020 as a result of heavy rainfall.

results.name: Regional Population Movement - Afghanistan | Preparedness and Response
results.summary:
The evolving situation in Afghanistan is increasingly creating new potential drivers and triggers for cross-border displacement. The 2021 Afghanistan Humanitarian Needs Overview identified 18.4 million people in need of humanitarian assistance with 6.3 million being in extreme or catastrophic severity of needs; this figure is now likely to have increased due to the recent events in country. The situation remains uncertain in Afghanistan and may evolve rapidly.

Afghanistan faces an alarming humanitarian emergency and a worsening economic crisis, both likely to be further compounded by the approaching winter season. Almost half the population faces colossal humanitarian needs wrought by a combination of crises: displacement, devastation of COVID-19 pandemic, drought, acute food shortages, a fractured health system, poor access to services, and restrictive social norms. More than 558,000 Afghans have been internally displaced by the conflict since January 2021, 80 per cent of these newly internally displaced are women and children.

According to the drought declaration by the Afghanistan government of 22 June 2021, the country’s wheat crop will be reduced by nearly two million tons, and more than three million livestock are in danger of perishing due to a lack of fodder and water. IPC new projections for the period June – November 2021 estimates that, 2,742,741 Afghans are likely to be classified in Phase 4 (catastrophic) in terms of Food Insecurity and 6,719,607 in Phase 3 (emergency). The compounding impacts of drought and conflict which escalated in July and the first half of August have exacerbated the hard living conditions in a country that is also grappling with COVID-19 and poverty. Access to banking services has been severely constrained, with cashflow crippled. Collapse of Afghanistan’s economy would result in catastrophic consequences for vulnerable Afghans, including potentially fueling cross-border movements for economic reasons.

Therefore, based on analysis of the ongoing social, economic, political and security situation in Afghanistan, it is assessed that a further political and humanitarian deterioration in the country is likely to result in new population movements to neighbouring countries. A potential worst-case scenario – utilized by the UNHCR and inter-agency partners - envisages the arrival of an additional 515,000 Afghan refugees into neighbouring countries before the end of 2021.

Any major population movement will require an immediate and sustained humanitarian intervention in neighbouring countries. This will include critical life-saving humanitarian assistance at border points and in designated sites in coordination with respective authorities.

There are up to six million Afghans living outside of Afghanistan – in Europe, Asia Pacific and the Middle East - following several decades of instability in the country. New arrivals in 2021 will join more than 2.2 million registered refugees who have fled previous waves of insecurity, instability and violence to neighbouring countries. There are a further 3 million Afghans with varying status including many irregular migrants, who have been hosted in the Islamic Republic of Iran and the Islamic Republic of Pakistan over the past four decades. It will be important to maintain humanitarian assistance and protection for both new arrivals, and those previously displaced, as well as host communities.

Beyond the scope of this Emergency Appeal, there may also be onward movements and humanitarian needs in secondary countries, with Afghans taking routes to Turkey, Greece and the Western Balkans region. It will be critical to both monitor these trends and developments, as well as to be prepared and ready to provide increased principled humanitarian assistance and protection along existing migratory routes to those on the move– irrespective of their status – and to host communities in secondary countries.

field_reports.description:
On July 10, 2021, at 07:14 local time, an earthquake was registered in the country. The epicentre of the earthquake was located 165 km northeast of Dushanbe and 21 km east of the Rasht region.
The strength of the tremors in the epicenter was 5 - 6 points, in Dushanbe 2 - 3 points. Five people (mother and four children) reported to be killed in the village Busto of Langari Shoh Jamoat, Tajikabad District.
Over 30 people in Tajikabad District reported to be injured and two hospitalized. Local authorities reports that earthquake caused severe damages to the housing infrastructure in Tajikabad and Rasht districts.

field_reports.description:
As a result of intense rains heavy rains within May 5-12, 2021 in the territory of a number of districts of the Khatlon region and the DRS, mudflows were recorded, which, unfortunately, entailed human casualties. As a result of the disaster, damage was recorded to residential buildings, household plots, arable land, destruction of auxiliary structures, as well as erosion of the roadway. 

By May 12, 2021 according to last information:

•	58 houses totally damaged
•	123 houses partially damaged
•	56 auxiliary buildings were damaged
•	100 land plots were affected
•	167 families evacuated 
Due to on-going rainy days, the scale of damages can be grown and the number of damages will be changed.

The torrential rains of May 7–13, 2021 triggered floods, landslides and mudflows in many of the country’s districts. The largest number of losses and destructions are faced by districts and cities of Khatlon province. Disasters affected following cities and districts: Kulob town and districts of Shamsiddini Shohin, Yovon, Dusti, Vaksh, Muminobod and Abdurahmoni Jomi.
CoES reports that disasters caused the death of 9 people. Very preliminary estimates indicate that households were left homeless and houses of 907 households were damaged to different extents.                                   

Very	modest	estimations	indicate	damages caused by disasters to private and social infrastructure caused disruptions to the livelihoods of more than 22,000 people.

Government of Tajikistan activated an Inter-Agency Commission on Emergency Situations (Commission) in each disaster affected district, which fully facilitates the response operations. Furthermore, Emergency Operations Centers (Shtab) have been set up in each disaster affected district, which collects and analyzes relevant information and coordinates the response activities.

Up to date, general response actions in every district include: search and rescue, evacuation of population from risk zones, constant disinfection of the affected territories, debris removal, assessment of damages and needs, registration of affected population, restoration of communal services, collection and distribution of immediate relief assistance, as well as recovery planning.

field_reports.description:
According to the last information received on April 30, 2021 from Mrs.Malikova Sharifakhon, RCST Isfara town branch volunteer and Mr. Juraev Zikriddin the Chairman of the RCST primary organization in Somonien village, the situation in the border area is still tense. 
Beginning from 30/04/2021 at 01am (midnight) till morning, the most vulnerable population from local inhabitants (women, children and elderly) from Khojai Alo and Surkh villages were evacuated to the center of Isfara town. According to the information from RCST DM Coordinator in Isfara town, the evacuated people were located in 5 schools (each school hosted more than 300 people) and 2 tea houses (each place hosted more than 600 people), also some others were located to the houses of local population by their own initiatives of villages Zarkhok and Khushdevor in Navgilem jamoat, Isfara town.
